utterances: By making these investments in foreclosure prevention today, we will save ourselves the costs of foreclosure tomorrow, costs that are born not just by families with troubled loans, but by their neighbors and communities and by our economy as a whole.
In the meantime, Forbes.com has put together a list of the emptiest cities in America, all as a result of the credit crisis.
Joining me now is Zack O'Malley Greenburg.
He is the reporter behind the Forbes.com article.
Zack, welcome.
Mr.
ZACK O'MALLEY GREENBURG (Reporter, Forbes.com): Hi, Tony.
How are you?
I'm fine.
Thank you.
Which cities are the - are in the top five of America's emptiest cities, Zack?
Mr.
O'MALLEY GREENBURG: Well, the top five - the fifth is Dayton, fourth is Greensboro, third is Atlanta, second is Detroit, and first is Las Vegas.
All on there for - for kind of different root causes but, you know, the situation is getting a little more dire as more jobs kind of go to wayside.
Let's talk about what those causes are because Las Vegas was just recently known as the fastest growing city in America.
And I know personally that there's been a great deal of building there, a lot of it coming from California and other places.
But what's behind this, particularly as it relates to Las Vegas and Detroit?
Mr.
O'MALLEY GREENBURG: Sure.
Well, Tony what we have here is, you know, two really different situations.
Although it looks the same on the surface because they both have a lot of vacancies both in rental and in homeowners, the fact is that it's due to two really different root causes.
With Vegas, you know, it was sort of burgeoning into the shimmering urban carnival of the city and, you know, lots of Californians building second homes there, buying condos in high rises.
But Detroit's had problems for a long, long time.
And the downturn really kind of hit both of them in different ways.
So, with Vegas it was more of a - it was more of a matter of overcapacity.
There were all these new condos going up, all these second homes out in the suburbs.
And suddenly the market dried up and, you know, people had to sell their second homes and stopped renting in Vegas.
Then in New York - I'm sorry, in Detroit what happened was, you know, Detroit has been hemorrhaging jobs for decades and it's certainly not getting any better.

You see in the news with everything going on with the car companies, you know, it's not like things are getting better, not like people are getting more money to rent more houses and buy more houses there.
So, you know, that's kind of been the problem in Detroit for a lot longer.
Well, you mentioned rentals.
That was going to be my next question because the issue isn't only with buying, it's also with rentals.
What's happening there?
Mr.
O'MALLEY GREENBURG: Sure.

I mean, again, you know with rentals, especially in places like Vegas, there was an overcapacity and a lot of developers started building giant, you know, giant residential towers in the thoughts that the boom would continue.
And you know the rental market really dried up even quicker.
What did you find on the flipside?
We know about the cities now that are the emptiest, what about those that are doing well in terms of their housing?
You know, I think actually the imagination is at the center of them and my show is just me.
So I felt that that was a big challenge, to make people fall in love with me and with what I surrounded myself with.
But I think we did a good job.
I think it's a really pretty show.
It's beautiful.
We have gorgeous girls.
The costumes are a delight.
It's a visual feast, really, and there I am in the middle, just being the ring master and it's a lot of fun.
Let's get some callers on the line.
Our guest, of course, Bette Midler.
Email is talk@npr.org, and this is Hala(ph), Hala with us from California.
Hello.
It's Paula.
Paula, I'm sorry.
Our screener mistyped your name.
I apologize.
Don't worry about that.

Well, you had asked about some memories or first exposures to the ""Divine,"" and if I had to name, you know, one of my top ten albums of my life, ""The Divine Miss M"" is right up there, and the memory I just wanted to share was my sister was the lead.

She was always Miss M, and the other sisters would stand behind her and we'd lip-sync and be the Harlettes as my sister belted out the songs from ""The Divine Miss M."" So that was a great memory I have of that album.
Do you still listen to it?
The other part was the two versions of ""Friends"" on that album, the funny version and the serious version.
And I make a CD when we travel, and I have few friends that I travel with to Reno, and that we hit the part when we're just coming into Reno where we always play ""Friends.
Oh, that's great.
What a wonderful story.
And does it bring you luck?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Sometimes yes and sometimes no.
Welcome to Vegas!
Just getting the four of us to get away from our job at the same time and be able to go away for the weekend.
Well, Paula.
Very sweet.
Good luck next time.
Yes, yes.
Nice to meet you and nice to hear the stories of what you're doing.
I'll try to get down to Vegas to see you.
Terrific, thank you.
So long.
Let's see if we can get - this is Daniel.
Daniel with us from Conway in Arkansas.
Yes, sir.
Appreciate your putting me on.
Bette, I just wanted to express my thanks for inspiring many through the years.
You're my oldest sister's personal hero, and she turned out to be a great singer.
And I'm a recently fired journalist who's going to go and try to pursue his musical career.
And I really have always admired the way your flamboyant and boisterous attitude when performing and it inspires a lot of people.
A few years ago I caught that movie you did on cable, ""The Rose,"" in which I believe you were portraying Janis Joplin.

And you've probably been asked about this a million times, I wanted to see if maybe you could talk to the listeners a little bit about how you prepared for that, and if you could tell if you had ever met her before.
You know, I didn't meet Janis but I was a big fan of hers.
And you know, they came to me and asked me if I would do the Janis Joplin story.
And I was such a big fan I thought that I'd - it would be a mistake to take her as my inspiration.
So you know, we sort of reworked a whole lot of things about that script.
But I mean, ultimately, everybody thought it was Janis but in my mind it never was because I had been on the road since I - since about 1968, I guess.
And in my travels, you know, doing shows and you know, rock n' roll shows and all sorts of shows, I kind of got the picture of what it was like to be a female in that environment.
And so I used many of my memories from those days, and I helped out with the clothes, and I helped out with the - I helped out with some of the staging.
It remains my favorite picture because it was - it had so much going for it, you know?
It had terrific music, it had a great band, it had a wonderful story.
And really, the opportunity to do - to really chew the scenery, I mean, but in the best possible way.
And so I mean - but I had so much support on that picture.
Everybody loved the script and everybody really wanted it to succeed.
And it did.
You know, it really sort of sent me on my way.
So it remains one of my favorite - actually, my favorite of all the pictures I've done.
I've read that it cost you, though.
It might have.
What happened?
Tell me what I said.
That you had problems with your voice after that.
I did have trouble with my voice.
And I had - I actually had a lot of trouble singing for that producer.
It was Paul Rothschild, a guy who had worked with Jimmy Morrison.
And he had also worked with Janis.
He had worked with Bonnie Raitt, people like that.
And he was good, but he was a very hard taskmaster.
And I really literally sang till I bled.
And it was hard.
It was a very, very hard - it was very hard.
And I never - the hard part, the rough part about being in show business is a lot of times the work is so deadly, so hard, that you forget.
Even if it's a success, all you have with you are your memories of how hard it was and how, you know, what the struggle was.

And that's a drag because sometimes these pieces of material or the shows or whatever are so - people love them so much, and it would be better if you could remember the great parts and not just the parts where you suffered.
Daniel, thanks very much for the call.
Thanks, Neal.
You know that voice?
We're talking with Bette Midler, and she's taking your calls.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
(Soundbite of song ""I've Still Got My Health"")
(Singing) The sight of my props never stops a thoroughfare, but I still got my health, so what do I care?
Your face is your fortune, so some wise men spoke.
My face is my fortune, that's why I'm totally broke.
My ship ain't come in, but I grin while I bear, 'cause I got my vitamins: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H.
I still have my.
Got no diamonds, got no wealth.
I got no men, but I got my health.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
In 1970, the legendary Johnny Carson retired, and one of his last guests was Bette Midler.
Yeah.
Bette Midler with Johnny Carson in 1992.
She's with us today.
She may not win an Emmy for this appearance, though.
If you'd like to speak with her, our number is 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And Paul's with us, Paul calling from Grand Bank in Michigan.
Hello, Neal.
Thanks for taking my call.
Ms. Midler, it's a thrill to hear you.
I'd like to go back a little bit further.
Many years ago, more than we'd both like to admit, I guess, when I was watching...
But I look fabulous.
I still look great.
